title: Can you bifurcate a marriage while in Chapter 7 Bankruptcy?
question: are there any special steps or processes? Is Bankruptcy court approval necessary
question_tags: Divorce,Dissolution of marriage,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce court,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Tax law,State court
answers: Bifurcation refers to the dissolution of marriage process where the State court separates the actual dissolution of the marriage from the resolution of property issues which are dealt with later on.

Chapter 7 Bankruptcy normally only lasts about thirty days from filing date to discharge date, then the case is closed. So it is a small window of time. I am not aware of any restriction for a couple who wants to separate, file for dissolution or divorce, etc., to obtain court permission. But review with your attorney before doing anything.

If you want to divorce after you file a Chapter, you may do so. However, the divorce court cannot decide who gets what assets and pays what debts until your Chapter 7 is complete or you ask for permission (relief from stay / asset abandonment) in the Chapter 7. But, Chapter 7's typically last only three months. So, to save some money, you might start all the divorce prep work now but file it after the 7 is complete.

What you are asking for may be possible, but it isn't necessary. Here's why.

When you are your spouse filed a joint bankruptcy, you were actually both in two separate bankruptcies that were jointly adminstrated. She has her debt; you have your debts; two bankruptcy estates were created, completely separate from one another. It's the same as filing a joint tax returns: there are actually two separate returns filed, with amounts owed to the respective spouses. We file joint bankruptcy and joint taxes because it is faster and easier for the government to administer them. In the case of a joint bankruptcy filing, you also benefit from saving of another filing fee.

That said, you do not become responsible for your wife's sole debts, and vice versa.

Further, in a no-asset chapter 7 bankruptcy, which is likely the kind of case you are in, no debts are paid bank anyway. So there is no need to bifurcate the case.

One exception is if there is joint tax debt. If you have a tax debt that is largely belonging to your spouse, you should speak with your attorney about opening a dialog with the IRS (or filing a lawsuit, if necessary) to determine the exact amount of money each spouse owes.

Hope this helps!

It is unclear what you are asking. Bifurcate isn't a word typically applied to marriage within the context of bankruptcy. Bifurcating typically applies to a court case, not a relationship. Hope this perspective helps!
Yes, I think there is a word for bifurcating a marriage -- divorce.
